website_summaries.verdict: Tiltable screen on the scanner makes it more comfortable to use as you're scanning the negatives and slides.
pros: Saves your digital photos to a memory card up to 128 gigabytes in size, meaning you don't need to be connected to a computer
Has a 3.5-inch LCD screen that will tilt so you can use it comfortably
Supports scanning of 35 millimeter, 126, 110, Super 8, and 8 millimeter negatives and slides
Can view images on a TV with HDMI port
cons: Can only create digital images up to 14 megapixels in resolution, so the scanned images will not be pristine

customer_reviews.title: Poor quality control
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this scanner and it stopped working after one scan. I called "DBroth" (the seller) and they said I had to push the "on" button for a few seconds. That didn't work so I returned it. I purchased a second one from DBroth and it had a scratch on the lens and a white dot. Those both showed up on all the slides I scanned. There is no way to clean those items off because they are on the inside. So I returned that scanner. Now I am buying my 3rd scanner from DBroth and hoping the third time is a charm. Kodak should be a good product, but obviously the quality control is not there.
customer_reviews.author: ez2bfree

customer_reviews.title: Does not work for slides
customer_reviews.text: I got this to convert slides from the 70s. The very flimsy plastic gadget you put the slide into does not hold it in place. It moves as it is put in machine so there is no telling what portion of slide you will see. Sometimes it is most of it, sometimes it's none. So VERY DISAPPOINTED. (When I contacted Seller, they just sent auto reply with the Amazon return instructions .)
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Worth every penny
customer_reviews.text: Easy setup great product for very little money. I have hundreds if not thousands, of black and white negatives that I no longer have a darkroom to handle, I was able to scan over a hundred in the first evening. The preview screen allowed me to skip the poor shots saving me time
customer_reviews.author: Gentleman Jim

customer_reviews.title: Quality is not very good!
customer_reviews.text: I expected the quality Kodak has been famous for. I may have received a lemon but this one could not be used. The scans were all soft and out of focus yet some would be sharp? That was the worst issue however they also looked muddy and grey. Trying to adjust did not make things much better. Very unhappy with it and returned it.
customer_reviews.author: Sterling Thompson

customer_reviews.title: Made great photos!
customer_reviews.text: I live this! Was able to save hundreds of photos , some taken back in the 1940s! Would have cost me a fortune to have them done professionally and the quality is very good!
customer_reviews.author: luv2read

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: Everything comes out as negative not positive. So all my scans are still negatives.
customer_reviews.author: amelia b

customer_reviews.title: Get all your work done quickly.
customer_reviews.text: Initially I liked this product because it was easy to use and worked well. That only lasted for about two hours for the first use. The second use lasted for about five minutes and then it died. It cost me almost $100 per hour of use. Too late for return or product support. Unfortunate for me because I have literally thousands of slides to convert. Kodak doesn't appear to be a quality product like the old days. May or may not order the same one depending on prices and consumer reviews.
customer_reviews.author: Gaia

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: The quality was awful and the trays used were flimsy and hard to line up.
customer_reviews.author: Chad/Tina

customer_reviews.title: It worked great for one day then stopped
customer_reviews.text: It worked great for one day then stopped. Unit was returnd was received by them on 6/1. Today no new device and its been 2 weeks. No shipping info. Big question?
customer_reviews.author: Irv

customer_reviews.title: A good product. Easy to set up and use
customer_reviews.text: A good product. Easy to set up and use. Clear interface. Scans slides and negatives quickly. Resolution acceptable. Would recommend it for the casual user. Not a product for high resolution work.
customer_reviews.author: Walter F.

customer_reviews.title: Kodak Moments
customer_reviews.text: Inlaws asked me to digify about 2000 slides. No big deal, right? Wrong. If I messed up their sacred memories, my life wouldn't be worth a plug nickel. Took a chance on this device. Works like a charm. Now, I'm the favorite. My husband married well. Thanks, Kodak.
customer_reviews.author: Sparkle1122

customer_reviews.title: VERY NICE!!!!
customer_reviews.text: This is a really nice scanner. It is very user friendly and gives very exceptional scans. I had no issues with any of the formats that I scanned. From slides to negatives, this little guys performed perfectly. I would highly recommend this unit to anyone.
customer_reviews.author: WoodWorker

customer_reviews.title: Poor Resolution, poor JPEG quality
customer_reviews.text: I expected more from the Kodak brand name. If you don't care about resolution quality, this might be OK. 1. The time/date is not settable. 6/1/2017 is used. 2. Does not scan full 35mm negative. The standard 35mm filmstrip that contains 36mm x 24mm frames. This unit scans approximately 35mmx22mm, so you have to decide what to crop. 3. JPEG compression is very poor. 4. File resolution is 14MP or 22MP, but the 22MP is "interpolated" according to the users manual. 5. Actual scanned resolution is much less than the file resolution. At 14MP I would expect 3200dpi resolution, but the actual resolution looks more like a smudged 800dpi.
customer_reviews.author: Shannon

customer_reviews.title: Purchase a scandisc first!
customer_reviews.text: We love it! Takes a bit of practice, but then very easy to use. Having trouble with slides not pushing through? Try tray #3. The thinner tray, #1,may cause problems with slightly warped slides jamming. Larger tray can cause overlapping. Takes a bit of fiddling, but I now have access to great slide shows of slides over 40 years old. Highly recommend importing into Windows Live photo program. Don't bother with adjusting in Scanza-just push 'capture'- much easier to do in computer. Also, do not re-orient vertical slides. Orient them all horizontally or you will lose some of picture. Rotate after importing. Worth every penny....
customer_reviews.author: Marguerite B.

customer_reviews.title: color negs and b/w negs - its painless to get images that are good enough for use as memories from 4 decades ago
customer_reviews.text: its not a deluxe thing, but works quite well, and beats all the alternatives. I may even give it five stars after a year. I did a quick trial on old slides, color negs and b/w negs - its painless to get images that are good enough for use as memories from 4 decades ago. It does NOT tell you which side up to put your negative or slide, it seems to need the images to be emulsion side down, which is less than ideal.
customer_reviews.author: Anthony J. Hitchings

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use out-of-the-box
customer_reviews.text: Used to upload 50 year-old 35mm color slides to college reunion Website. Worked like a charm. Easy and intuitive to use. Simply edited the pictures using the old Microsoft Paint software program (resizing and cropping was needed) before finally posting on the Website. Pictures look terrific.
customer_reviews.author: D. K. Willis

customer_reviews.title: Couldn't get mine to work with 35mm slides.  Useless owners manual
customer_reviews.text: Much cheaper construction than I expected. Large picture of it on Amazon is deceiving. It's small and light weight plastic. Kind of looks like a toy. Manual is unreadable and in about 4 pt type with screen images that are impossible to make out. When I assembled and plugged it in, I could not get the navigation buttons to go to 35mm slide setting. I watched an online tutorial which showed what one is supposed to do, but my navigation buttons would not do what the tutorial showed. After 2 hours of screwing around I packed it up drove to UPS and sent it back for refund. Very disappointing experience.
customer_reviews.author: David N. Mead

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use!
customer_reviews.text: If your looking to scan and save old slides, I would highly recommend this. We scanned and saved over 2000 slides in 2 days. Now there may be a few I want to take and have professional done, but over all the quality is prefect. My slides date back to the late 1960s
customer_reviews.author: Donna D.

customer_reviews.title: Avoid
customer_reviews.text: This should be a fairly simple device to just take a picture of your negative or slide and put that information on a digital card. Unfortunately I found it impossible to put a strip of 35 mm. negatives through the adapter that goes into the scanner without removing the adapter for each and every darned strip of film. Inevitably the film hangs or buckles, sometimes ruining the negative. So instead of just being a worthless piece of crap it's actually worse than worthless. I would gladly pay someone to set this device on fire. Think I'll just pack it up and send it back. I am not even faintly amused.
customer_reviews.author: Arthur Hampton

customer_reviews.title: Horribly inconsistent scans
customer_reviews.text: Bought this to scan my collection of 35 mm negatives. The device is easy enough to operate but scans are very inconsistent. As you can see attached, two consecutive scans of the very same negative, without moving the negative or making any setting changes, will yield wildly different results. Returning the scanner.
customer_reviews.author: Willem R. Vandenberge

customer_reviews.title: Good scanner.
customer_reviews.text: Scanner arrived promptly and was very easy to set up. I'm pleased with the scanning results, but I may need to reposition slides to avoid cutting off part of the image. Two suggestions: First, make it easier to remove slides from the adapter tray. Removing slides is the most laborious part of the process. Second, make it clear that the "Kodachrome label" on slides is face down in order to avoid reversing the images. I bought this scanner for the sole purpose of scanning Kodak slides; I expect this is the major market and this tip would be helpful.
customer_reviews.author: Jim59

customer_reviews.title: everything as promised
customer_reviews.text: Although, it's expensive, this machine is well designed. I had about 2,500 slides from the 1980's and 90's that I wanted to turn into digital copies. This device allowed me to accomplish the job reasonably quickly and successfully. One problem beyond the control of this machine, is that some slides warp slightly as they age. So a warped slide will not feed smoothly across the insert-guide. With some frequency, I had to manually single-feed a slide (due to warping). But overall this didn't slow me down. Copying each image is very quick taking only 2-4 seconds. Be sure to buy a memory card. They are not expensive. Now, what do I do with 20 Kodak slide carousels?
customer_reviews.author: occasional consumer 1

customer_reviews.title: Good quality unit, easy to use.
customer_reviews.text: A moderately priced consumer grade device that works well. Relatively easy to slide my 35mm negatives through, and the review / scanning process is quick. The resulting image file is of reasonably good quality - not suitable for big enlargements, but to get that probably requires a significantly more expensive unit, not to mention the time spent mounting the negatives. I think I managed to process 500 slide images in just over an hour. The built-in image controls are handy as well, I primarily use them to control brightness.
customer_reviews.author: Subman

customer_reviews.title: What a find
customer_reviews.text: I've had boxes and boxes of slides laying around for years not knowing what to do with them. Started looking for best way to scan them to digital and read an article about this Kodak Scanza. Had good reviews so I got one. While it's a little tricky at first adjusting the color correctly, once you get started you can just blow through one box after another. The image you see on the screen isn't perfect, but the image it saves is almost perfect. A little touching up with just Paint, and you've got a perfect picture.
customer_reviews.author: NavyMom

customer_reviews.title: Poor scan quality. Colour off.
customer_reviews.text: Way overpriced for a poor quality tool. Colour is off with only one simple (inadequate) tool for correction, and that does not retain the setting when shut off. No way to set the device date for file names. So EVERY time it is used if begins with the file name IMG00001.JPG 6/1/2017 1:17AM. For the cost of this device it should have a battery and way to increment names of all photos scanned and retain the date. Complete PITA for cataloging files. Additionally quality is poor. Very unhappy with this purchase.
customer_reviews.author: Michigan Craftsman

customer_reviews.title: Does not work. Worked short time.. detective ...
customer_reviews.text: Does not work . Worked short time.. detective. Got item and seal to box was broken.
customer_reviews.author: Kara Dorsey

customer_reviews.title: Good Value for light use.
customer_reviews.text: For the person who wants to wade through old slides and some film negatives, this will work well. The various adaptors for the variety of film/slides are plastic and should be handled with care. After a slight learning curve, it is fairly easy to use. Resolution should be good enough for most applications. My minor annoyance is with the length of the power cord which is 48". Given that the average desk is 30", you have very little slack to plug it in and move it around on the desk. Making the cord 72" would be helpful. It is a minor point, but I don't like having to use an extension cord every time I use it.
customer_reviews.author: mttopper

customer_reviews.title: It's a fast way to do a lot
customer_reviews.text: I scanned 3,000 135 color slides some of which were faded from the 1960s. all the way back to 1948! All were in good physical shape, some cardboard, some superslides, and some in plastic holders. Any processing I left for photo shop, but I had a very good rendition of the data which remained in the film positives. Use this scanner to get the film data into digital form. With good slide condition as mine were, slides go through very quickly. You use a push feed and the carrier does very well. Good value. No scanner could have been satisfactory automatically adjusting image. That up to you and Photo Shop or whatever you have mastered
customer_reviews.author: critic

customer_reviews.title: Its what I expected.
customer_reviews.text: Good little tool to review your old film content while hunting for past pictures of interest. Super easy to use. Buy an updated LARGE capacity SD chip to accompany if you're planning to use the scan feature.
customer_reviews.author: Matt Mullen

customer_reviews.title: Very Complete
customer_reviews.text: Love it! Has all of the items needed to digitise photos and for a very reasonable price. I have thousands of negatives and slides to convert. It is a slow and tedious process with any scanner, but I find this one to reproduce in a very quality fashion. Highly recommend for one with time and patience.
customer_reviews.author: Ed B

customer_reviews.title: Decent Quality
customer_reviews.text: I purchased both the Wolverine and the Kodak digital converters. I started with the Kodak and transferred a few 1000 negatives. I missed the fact that when I purchased the Kodak that it does not support APS negatives, so I subsequently purchased the Wolverine. In summary, the Wolverine is easier to use, nice features for flipping images if you didn't insert the negative correctly. The Kodak isn't quite as feature rich, but with side by side 35mm negatives, the Kodak outperformed the Wolverine in image quality.
customer_reviews.author: RDR

customer_reviews.title: Really like it
customer_reviews.text: Good unit for the price. Looking to transfer my slides to computer and this fit the bill. Small size, does a good job of scanning too. There are better but for home pictures I don't need a 4000 dollar unit. I have only run about 50 slides through it and a few have hung on the transport but probably some flash that will wear down. No scratches to the film anyway. Scans fast too. Selecting the film size and transport is easy too. Overall for home pictures its a great unit. Would have given it 5 stars if the transport didn't jam every so often.
customer_reviews.author: Stephen N. House

customer_reviews.title: My Husband Loves This Thing
customer_reviews.text: We have many sets of negatives from the past 40 years and we were hoping to the find a piece of equipment that would help us digitally archive our precious photos. This Kodak Scanza was exactly what we needed. The photos are crisp and the color is great and everything is easily transferred to card or stick. The only issue is with black and white photos that look red. This is easily remedied with our Canon Photo Editing program. My husband found the Scanza easy hookup and use with no fuss.
customer_reviews.author: KDQ

customer_reviews.title: The unit would never turn on!
customer_reviews.text: This sounds like a great product, and I realize it has received all kinds of great reviews, but I cannot get the unit I just received to turn on no matter what I do. I even replaced the USB cable that came with the unit hoping that might solve the situation but to no avail.
customer_reviews.author: Jack

customer_reviews.title: Convenient.  Size and shape are just right!
customer_reviews.text: This will finally replace my other 3 slide copiers and I can get rid of them. Now I watch TV with this in my lap and a box of slides next to me and run them through! I may actually get my decades of slides where they can be seen!
customer_reviews.author: R. Barnard

customer_reviews.title: great scanner at a reasonable price
customer_reviews.text: Overall the unit is excellent. good quality construction (slide holders could be beefier). As noted picture quality is very good as is. We did not do any serious editing, saving that for later. Once you get the hang of it, you can process a 100 slide tray in 30 to 45 min. The scan is fast, the mechanical load-unload is the slower part. We are finishing up a 1400 slide project and are very pleased. By the way a 32Gb SD card will hold a ton of pictures.
customer_reviews.author: boilerhoosier

customer_reviews.title: When scanning slides ...
customer_reviews.text: A longtime owner of increasingly expensive Canon scanners, I found the adaptations required for slide or negative scanning a genuine distraction. Getting some 50 year old slides ready for a funeral service finally convinced me to give up on the Canon. A quick check on Amazon found the Kodak Scanza. This is the obvious answer to anyone who wants to convert old slides and negatives quickly and easily to a digital format for printing or sharing. The Scanza is not inexpensive, but it does the job ... and quickly. I give it my highest marks.
customer_reviews.author: J. Foster

customer_reviews.title: Do not assume I am a techno geek....
customer_reviews.text: Sheesh.....you really would think that the instructions for a piece of equipment would start with diagrams and instructions about how to assemble it for use - this cord goes here, etc., but not so much. Apparently, Kodak believes that the purchasers of this gadget are fascinated with taking components out of bags and contemplating how they all go together. But no, they jump right in with which slides go in which trays. Elementary, people!!!!!!!!
customer_reviews.author: Murphy

customer_reviews.title: Flimsy, cheesy, and cheap, but it works
customer_reviews.text: It's pretty disappointing to open the box with this product and see how flimsy and cheap it appears. The film/slide holder set up is the worst part. Very rudimentary, and using it has the feel like a jerry-rigged (and jury-rigged; there is a difference) set up, but it does work. The picture quality is satisfactory, and probably more dependent on the condition of the slide or film being copied that the fidelity of the copying process.
customer_reviews.author: LSSR22

customer_reviews.title: Good basic scanner
customer_reviews.text: I bought this to scan a bunch of old slides from my parents and grandparents. Overall, this did a good job. The image quality at 22MP is good, but certainly doesn't approach the quality of a high-res film scanner. For what I was using it for, capturing memories, it was absolutely good enough with the added benefit of very fast scans - just a couple seconds, vs minutes for a high-res scanner. The included carriers worked well for negatives and slides. Old glass slides were too thick for the carriers, but slid in without a carrier and scanned fine, as did larger 120 negatives. They just took a little manual alignment.
customer_reviews.author: Garry Kolb

customer_reviews.title: Digitize your memories
customer_reviews.text: This scanner is straight-forward to use. It does a good job of scanning negatives and slides. The files created are decent enough for viewing on a computer screen or printing. However, enlarging or making prints of a portion of a scanned negative is limited in resolution. The tray to be used for 35mm slides will sometimes hang on a slide mount. I get around that by pulling the tray and manually encouraging the slide past the hang-up. Scanning negatives, both black & white and color worked surprisingly well. I was able to zip through a box of old negatives in a reasonable amount of time.
customer_reviews.author: jemorti

customer_reviews.title: does as claims...
customer_reviews.text: once you get it set up. But there are minimal directions on set up especially for a slider that is designed to be used in many countries , with many types of slides and has several types of insert possibilities. Can be plugged into a wall, a computer or a tv with cords for each and an odd hook up to the cords. Needed a computer savvy friend to help at first. Clearer and more basic directions on set up would be very helpful. Haven't tried to play with various settings much yet. Maybe I will learn to love it after I muddle through the settings more but directions should be clear enough so that isn't necessary
customer_reviews.author: Kindle CustomerJohn Kimball

customer_reviews.title: Love it. Have transferred over 1
customer_reviews.text: Love it. Have transferred over 1,000 slides and negatives to digital. It works just as expected with no problem loading or transferring. Quality of digital photo will depend on that of slides however many problems can be corrected on the computer
customer_reviews.author: fsymonds

customer_reviews.title: High quality fast scans
customer_reviews.text: I have over a thousand old slides to review and scan the ones worth keeping. (probably closer to 2000). This gadget scans almost as quickly as you can feed them through the delivery tray. The scans turn out great. I am now thinking about using it to capture stills from my dad's old 16mm home movies. It's set up to do that, too. I was on the border on this purchase (could have used a slide viewer and selected slides for professional scanning, but this definitely a less expensive and less time-consuming option. I'm very happy with this purchase.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew H. Stone

customer_reviews.title: Good value for the money.
customer_reviews.text: I am very pleased with this slide scanner. What I needed was to get reasonable scans of my slides very quickly and it suits that purpose quite admirably. It is important to note that while the digital sensor will produce a 14MB image (22 MB image with interpolation), the optics of this product do not support the full digital resolution one might expect of a 14MB image. And for the price of the device, that is to be expected. For most of my needs, the optical resolution is more than adequate and for those rare cases where I need something better, I can go have my slide scanned by a service.
customer_reviews.author: James Thayer

customer_reviews.title: Product works as described. Good value for the price.
customer_reviews.text: Have had scanner for about one month during which I’ve scanned about 15,000 images from 135mm slides and negatives. I then edit images in my Surface with MS picture editor. The sides go right through easily. The negatives are a little more difficult but with some jiggling you can usually get them through. I also have 110mm negatives and slides. As with 135mms the slides go through easily. The negatives are a little more complicated. I don’t use the 110mm plastic feeder as they get stuck in it. I feed them manually without the feeder. Considering the price paid it’s a good value and works as described. I would recommend the product.
customer_reviews.author: AAyebatz

customer_reviews.title: Great Value - One of the best purchases I've made this year.
customer_reviews.text: My Dad recently pasted away and he had a lot of pictures & negatives. Many in different format, 35mm, 126, 110, color, slides, B&W., etc. I converted over 1,000 negatives into digital files and was able to share them with family and friends. Only one drawback, is that 35mm is largest negative it supports. My Dad had some negatives were were twice the size of a 35. Otherwise this is a great product to have if you have negatives you want to convert to digital files.
customer_reviews.author: Wilson Yuen

customer_reviews.title: Does what you need it to do
customer_reviews.text: This is a good product and have used it several times to date. Intuitive menu and you can be up and running in just a few minutes after unpacking it. The one downside I found is that every time you want to advance the negative to the next frame, you have to remove the film holder, open the lid, slide the negative to the desired frame, close the lid, and reinsert the film holder into the scanner. I realize it is "tight" as to hold the film securely and flat, but it seems overly tight such that the negative won't budge. Otherwise, solid product with nice features!
customer_reviews.author: Jeff H

customer_reviews.title: Impressive.
customer_reviews.text: Finally you can now view all the unconnected slides & negatives lying about in those old shoe boxes. The quality of the images which I have scanned at the lowest of the two settings are excellent. The Kodak Scanza offers trays for all film sizes from 8mm to 135 positive/ negatives, (which are not always included with other photo scanners.) The controls are relatively simple to operate. But it's important to note that the only extra which is required for the Kodak Scanza is to have a SD card for memory. Simple to operate, high quality imaging, & fun to be able to see lost memories.
customer_reviews.author: E. Bradstreet

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use! Don't worry if you are not a geek.
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this machine to transfer over 1200 slides to digital files for my in-laws for a Christmas present. It's kinda one of those things that people want to do but never get around to it. It takes less than an hour to do a 100 slide carousel. Once they were on a SD card I transferred them to a USB thumb drive and DVD and gave it away as a Christmas present. I also made a thumb drive backup for my family and every time we have the in-laws over for dinner we stick the drive in our TV and select another folder on the drive and watch a slideshow. Huge hit, best present in years!
customer_reviews.author: Cory and Kim Hamilton

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use and quality of pictures is pretty good
customer_reviews.text: I had hundreds of 65 year old 3D slides (two 35mm pictures in on slide holder). I took a few of these to a local business that specialized in digitizing slides and negatives. It was very expensive and the quality was terrible. This little Kodak scanner produced results that were 100% better than the "professional" and the unit paid for itself with the first tray of slides I scanned. I'm very happy with the unit.
customer_reviews.author: Gazelle

customer_reviews.title: Fabulous, Easy to Use, Great Value!!!
customer_reviews.text: I bought this months ago and finally got around to transferring 23 carousels of 60 years of family slides. I'm not much of a tech wizard, and was thrilled with how easy to figure out and easy to use this compact little machine was. I wanted to make DVD's for family members (and get rid of all those slide boxes, too!!) as holiday gifts. Huge hit!!! I spent a long time shopping for what I thought would be the best slide transfer product to use and totally scored in my selection of this one. Highly recommend for anyone wanting to upgrade and store family memories!!!
customer_reviews.author: LuLu

customer_reviews.title: Almost Automatic
customer_reviews.text: Sorted about 1,000, 50 year old slides and saved about 120 to memory card in two days. The rest were either poor quality or had no one that we recognized in them ... they are no longer hanging around never being looked at. The process is fast. They autofocus in a second and save in about 3 seconds. We will tackle some old 8mm film next. I am sure that will be a slower process ... deciding which frames to save. We have not even owned a working projector in 30 years, but I do remember some priceless scenes that we captured when the girls were young.
customer_reviews.author: J. Maney

customer_reviews.title: Does exactly what it's supposed to -- preserve the most precious memories
customer_reviews.text: We used this scanner to convert over 1000 slides from my husband's family, including over 350 of my father-in-law's slides from his time serving our country during the Vietnam War. We then used Chatbooks to make an incredible hardcover book of all of his photos to give him for Christmas. He's been writing his own captions into the book ever since. This scanner has given us so much more than a digital record, it's given us an heirloom and has helped us to preserve a legacy.
customer_reviews.author: Kayla A.

customer_reviews.title: Great idea
customer_reviews.text: Setup and use are extremely fast. There are 2 things to know about this scanner: first, you are going to have to work to keep dust off the negatives and from getting on the scanning plate. Second, the scans are terrific for sharing online, but if you're planning to zoom in to touch them up, the detail is by no means sharp. Since I wanted to be able to do the scans myself inexpensively, I'm pretty happy with the results here. This is great way to see what's been bouncing around in that box of negatives in the closet for decades!
customer_reviews.author: John Johnson Jr.

customer_reviews.title: Requires an SD card to work
customer_reviews.text: The item will probably work as I expected. Or I assume it will after I receive the SD card. Without the card you can preview but nothing else. I only found one place (in questions) where it was indicated that it had to have the SDcard to work or I would have bought one when I bought the scanner. I didn’t mind buying it I just would like to have known upfront.
customer_reviews.author: Szipper

customer_reviews.title: Digitized 5000 slides
customer_reviews.text: i bought this to digitize approx 5000 slides, basically my whole childhood. Worked great! Took a minute to figure out I could just push the next slide in, capture, push slide in, capture, like an assembly line. I was doing them one at a time. The book says you can do this, but does not illustrate, so I didn't get it at first. The only negative thing I can say is that I thought I could digitize 8mm film. You can only do stills from the film. The description was not clear, or I read too much into it. It does not come with a SD card, so I had to make a quick trip to Walmart.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: pretty easy to use and saved a bunch of my ...
customer_reviews.text: Did not know what to really expect from a relatively inexpensive slide scanner. Found out it worked well, pretty easy to use and saved a bunch of my slides from over 50 years ago. The color adjustment is not very good, so I put the jpg through photo shop.
customer_reviews.author: tomshafer

customer_reviews.title: Great for the price!!!
customer_reviews.text: I have run over 12 years of negatives through my Scanza. It is a time consuming process having to do 1 negative at a time. But it was a nice trip through memory lane. As far as the picture quality goes it is pretty good. The picture quality is as good as the negative you run through it (if you have a crappy negative you get a crappy picture). It is easy to use and easy to set up. I am very happy to convert my negatives to to a digital format for a low price. I am happy because I can make copies of my digitized pictures since no one really processes negatives anymore (cheaply).
customer_reviews.author: Andrew Hernandez

customer_reviews.title: Good product, just keep it clean.
customer_reviews.text: Wherever you use this product dust very, very, very well and blow your negatives clean. Apart from irritating issues with dust, this product works very well. Selecting highest quality scans will give you 4mb image sizes. The product is very easy to use and pretty intuitive. The negative feeding mechanism is: your hand. I've found it's much better to put the correct negative tray in the machine and leave it there; don't try to remove it and reload it with every negative. Generally you can slide the negatives in one end and push them through. Short cut negatives ( three or two shots ) are a bit annoying to handle, but they can be pushed through with another negative strip.
customer_reviews.author: TBill

customer_reviews.title: best solution found so far
customer_reviews.text: I have just started using this device. I will say that it is incredibly easy to use. can get started in under 5 minutes. I have a lot of Ecktachrome and Kodachrome slides that I want to digitize so that I can back them up and give out copies. The biggest problem is that the slides are small and we live in an 1080HD world where 70 inch pictures are incredibly clear. these convert at 14meg or enhanced to 22meg. but blown up on a 24 inch monitor is different than printed 3x5 or 4x6 prints. just be realistic. like converting old VHS home movies. Not 1080HD to start
customer_reviews.author: cpatom

customer_reviews.title: Good for the price
customer_reviews.text: The product is easy enough to use, but the color adjustment increments need to be more subtle. Even after uploading the images to my computer, I have to make adjustments in the coloration again. Uploading can also be made easier, like being able to capture the image in the scanner and simultaneously uploading it into the computer. Right now this is not a feature because the USB port that is used to connect to the power is the same USB port that is needed to upload the scanned images. Otherwise, it is still a handy little machine.
customer_reviews.author: Shichons' Mom

customer_reviews.title: Very Poor Color With Slides
customer_reviews.text: I should have paid more attention to the negative reviews. Initially scanning color 35mm slides results in a totally washed out image, lacking any color depth at all. Using the color adjustment can help somewhat but is very tedious and still results in a sub-par, not acceptable image. I don't know what scanner the positive review people were using but it was nothing like mine. User manual is lacking in detail but you can figure it out with a little time. Kodak should we ashamed putting their name on this thing. It is being returned asap.
customer_reviews.author: Phil N.

customer_reviews.title: Quality product, easy to use
customer_reviews.text: All you need to do is purchase an SD card. The unit has simple buttons and an easy to understand interface. The results look great. I tried to hire a service to digitize my negatives and was planning to only keep 300 of 800 due to the cost. I sent them the negatives and they said they would only allow me to reduce the order by 20%. I had them return the negatives, purchased the Kodak Scanza unit and did them all myself while watching TV. Now I have all the images and it cost less than 1/2, plus I can now scan all my friends negatives too!
customer_reviews.author: Stephen Shooster

customer_reviews.title: Awesome to bring old memories back to life
customer_reviews.text: Scanned a bunch of 35 mm slides and 8mm film from the 60s and it went quickly. Slides were easy and could do many in a minute. Slides that were in good shape came out very nice - damaged slides not so much but what do you expect. 8mm film was in bad shape but still salvaged a lot of nice stills that preserved old memories. I have recommended this to two other people who bought one and they thanked me for introducing them to it. One of them did several thousand slides from the 50 and 60s and was delighted. The price benefit is awesome as well.
customer_reviews.author: Mr C

customer_reviews.title: Just what I needed!!
customer_reviews.text: I love that I was able to go through my 35mm negatives so easy to find photos I no longer had prints of. It was so so easy. 110 film is a little more difficult and to be blunt a total PAIN. They don't slide through as easily as the 135 negatives. My biggest problem now is it doesn't do disc negatives and it turns out, I have way more of those then anything. I might have to pass this down to my mother who has way more 35mm negatives then I did. Truly a great product though. The pictures looking at the screen are very clear. I'm glad I splurged.
customer_reviews.author: Dawne

customer_reviews.title: Mediocre Quality
customer_reviews.text: Does pretty good for 35 mm slides once you get the hang of it. Unsatisfactory for 8 mm movies.
customer_reviews.author: Family Hunter

customer_reviews.title: Good product, flexible formats
customer_reviews.text: I used this scanner to convert a mountain of 35mm and 110 slides as well as 35mm negatives and 110 negatives. It's simple to use. The slide/negative feed mechanism is a little clunky, but gets easier to use with practice. If there were a different, better mechanism not prone to jams, I would give this product 5 stars. One note...make sure you get an SD card with sufficient capacity to hold all your images, if possible. I finally got a 64GB card that made the process easier (Each image will be from 1 - 4 MB).
customer_reviews.author: Merle S. King

customer_reviews.title: Does not work for 110 negatives
customer_reviews.text: Works great for 33mm and other similar sized negatives, but it does not work for 110. when using the adaptor, the pictures are black. I tried just running them through the 33mm slide & they were too light (too close to the light source. I purchased a Wolverine Titan, which works great. Very happy with that, but unfortunately, missed the return window for this product.
customer_reviews.author: Julie Newman

customer_reviews.title: Very happy with purchase
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this to convert slides taken since the 1950s to a digital format. All the 35mm slides converted to JPEG quickly and easily. Unfortunately, I do have some slides taken with the 620 format that are missing the edges when converted. I knew this going in to the purchase. Kodak does not state that it can be used for 620 size. The biggest negatives of this unit is that you cannot use the USB to convert the slides and directly or indirectly immediately transfer them to a PC. It’s either convert the slides, or transfer them to the PC.
customer_reviews.author: Bubblehead598

customer_reviews.title: Adequate to save old negatives to save and share
customer_reviews.text: I had a different scanner that cost half of this one, but the SD slot did not work and I sent it back and got this one. I am happy with the picture quality, I am interested in saving 40+ year old negatives so I am not very critical. The film carriers are poor at best, but just the same as you get with any of these scanners at this price range. I am saving the pics to an SD card that I will copy to my computer and also save to an external hard drive, so three copies that I can print, or share via email or text. I am very satisfied overall.
customer_reviews.author: Art vR

customer_reviews.title: Not Bad
customer_reviews.text: So far so good. I just got it so I'm still tinkering with it. The first pictures turned out OK considering the negatives I'm scanning are 33 years old now. The unit can be powered via USB cable. You do not have to have 110 VAC plug necessarily. Now you will NEED a SD memory card in order to save your imagines BEFORE uploading to computer/PC. So for an amateur picture person like myself, it is OK by me. Remember to avoid touching your negatives. Finger prints tend to ruin the film as well as the scan.
customer_reviews.author: R. BERTRAND

customer_reviews.title: very cool and small digital film scanner
customer_reviews.text: love how compact this unit is - takes up very little room on my desk. So far I have only done slides with the cardboard type frames, and I am amazed at the quality of the photos. I love that you can edit the photos right on the scanner before saving them. Takes a little time due to having to push the slides thru one at a time but for the price, it's definitely worth it.
customer_reviews.author: Star326

customer_reviews.title: Kodak Scanza Digital Film & Slide Scanner
customer_reviews.text: I was looking for a reasonably priced slide scanner to convert my parents slides to jpegs. Having never done it before I was worried I wouldn't be able to figure it out. I was so happy the Kodak Scanza Digital Film & Slide Scanner was so easy to use! Considering the slides had been kept up on the 2nd floor of their garage, the color and picture quality came out great. They had some old film that I was able to scan as well. This is an excellent scanner for someone like myself to start out with. I love it!!
customer_reviews.author: Leigh G

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Product, Needs Auto Adjustments
customer_reviews.text: I used this to convert slides for a job and it was super easy to use. I only rate it 4 stars because the color and brightness balance has to be done manually for each slide (RGB and brightness). The levels of correction did not go far enough to get a true balanced color level. If they made an auto brightness and color feature with deeper ranges of correction it would be perfect.
customer_reviews.author: jstan022

customer_reviews.title: Excellent device for amateur photographers
customer_reviews.text: Excellent device. For amateur photography. Not intended for professional, high quality photography. If you want a quick and easy way to convert your slides, this Kodak scanner is more than enough. With some additional Photoshop adjustments I’ve obtained beautiful digital pictures that were lost in an old box. I have only converted slides (not negatives), more than 1500.
customer_reviews.author: Juan Espinosa

customer_reviews.title: The resolution is fine for viewing on a computer screen
customer_reviews.text: I was considering buying a more expensive scanner but opted for this because of the ease of scanning cherished 35 mm negatives strips from long ago. The resolution is fine for viewing on a computer screen, ipad or digital frame or printing up to 8x10.
customer_reviews.author: Andrew S

customer_reviews.title: Poor Quality Scans
customer_reviews.text: What an absolute piece of garbage. While it may be easy to use, the scan quality is horrendous. It up-samples a low quality image and attempts to pass it off as 22megapixels. In reality the scan quality is visibly worse than the 2megapixel scans I get from the local photo place. I would find it hard to recommend this product to anyone serious about photography, but if you’re in the market for a cheaper and quicker option, and need scans done fast, then perhaps this would work for you.
customer_reviews.author: Jacob Limpf

customer_reviews.title: Simply Impressed
customer_reviews.text: If I read one review, I must have read 100.....lots of comments so I can add little except to say this is one pretty neat gadget. I found 60 year old slides and ran them through this Scanza am was amazed at the results. I have not made any prints from my scans yet, but fully anticipate good results to at least 4x6. Of course I am scanning so I don't have to make prints, reduce the clutter of boxes upon boxes of slides and negatives, and still have my photo library. The vendor dbroth delivered earlier than expected and in perfect condition.
customer_reviews.author: Frederick L. Ashworth

customer_reviews.title: Didn't work for me - the reviews misled me
customer_reviews.text: Not at all what I was hoping for, or what the reviews led me to expect. Found the unit very difficult to use, and slow and cumbersome, both mechanically and software connection-wise. I returned it and went back to my old method, which is fast and easy and I highly recommend. I hate to be the odd man out, or to give anything one star, but if you can't use it, I guess that means it was a bust. It was for me. Search Amazon for the Polaroid slide duplicator. A fraction of the price and it works extremely well. Very fast too.
customer_reviews.author: Robert Bogash

customer_reviews.title: Compare to Wolverine
customer_reviews.text: I have an old model Wolverine and recently bought the Kodak. Keep in mind I have the old model Wolverine but much is unchanged The huge difference is loading slides. Kodak has a well designed loader that allows you to simply slide in the next slide. Wolverine requires loading slides into a three slide cassette, which is slow and cumbersome. Average time per slide is about four seconds with Kodak and about twenty seconds per slide Wolverine. This is huge when you have thousands of slides. It may have changed with the newer Wolverine but the Kodak has a very short exposure time, which was a major impediment to fast scans with the Wolverine. Highly recommend Kodak over Wolverine.
customer_reviews.author: Thomas Huntington

customer_reviews.title: Digital Film and Slide Scanner
customer_reviews.text: I'm not dissatisfied with this item, but also not exactly happy. For the price, I think it's inferior quality. I have been using, and though not easy to use, it does get the job done. Just ensure if I would have purchased if I had seen and been able to use prior. All the great marketing hype on the amazon page made it look like the best product on the market - not sure all the hype is true. Going to head to local camera shop and get a recommendation of an actual higher quality item moving forward. Recommendation to others, try to find one to test drive before you buy.
customer_reviews.author: skotti

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use - Does the job!
customer_reviews.text: I did about 1,000 35mm negatives in an evening (just a couple of hours). It is quick and easy as shown in a variety of YouTube videos. The pictures come out as good as the negatives are. I enjoyed looking at these old negatives and the digital photos that come from them using the Scanza device. For those special images, I did some post processing just as I normally would for any out of camera digital image using Paintshop Pro 2019 for white balance, sharpening, etc, if needed.
customer_reviews.author: Dale R. Palmer

customer_reviews.title: Extremely pleased!
customer_reviews.text: I am extremely pleased with this slide scanner! I did a lot of research on the internet, watched many videos, read tons of reviews, but still wasn't quite confident about purchasing any particular slide scanner. I finally decided to take the plunge on the Kodak Scanza since Amazon has such an amazing return policy and boy was I pleasantly surprised. I can't attest for the uses other than its functionality as a slide scanner, but that was absolutely fantastic. This will get lots of use in my family.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use
customer_reviews.text: I have hundreds of slides and negatives that I wanted to have digitized. Sending them out was going to be very expensive and I tried doing them myself with a piece of equipment I bought 15 years ago. It was really slow and it couldn’t do slides. The Kodak Scanza is wonderful. It is fast and easy. Keeping the lens lint free is easy. It downloads to the computer very quickly. I’d recommend this to anyone who wants to do their own negatives or slides.
customer_reviews.author: Reanna P

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use
customer_reviews.text: Worked well on my old slides and 35mm negatives. For shorter negative strips, you must pull out the carrier and advance the negative. Not a deal breaker, but time consuming when going through a big box of negatives! It would be nice if it had some kind of feeder mechanism to pull the shorter strips through. Feeder problem with 110 negatives. My old negatives are slightly curved and will not slide through the carrier without opening it up and tweaking it into the slots. Again, the shorter strips (which most of my 110's are) can't be fed through easily. Overall, it is simple and easy to use. Photo quality is good. I am happy with this product.
customer_reviews.author: trralston

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use, likely one of the better products on market but still takes time.
customer_reviews.text: Considering the difficulty in copying slides to digital format this apparatus works very well. Options are few to allow for rapid delivery of the slides to copy. This still takes handling slides individually. But the larger screen allows for clear recognition of what is on this line and there is an EC ability to move the slides through seamlessly and fairly quickly. It’s also much cheaper than sending them out especially since there are likely many slides that you don’t want to have copied. I had another apparatus that was older and this is a huge improvement.
customer_reviews.author: dgj

customer_reviews.title: Not the best quality product for the price.
customer_reviews.text: This was pretty flimsy and a pain to use. The tray that loads the negatives is really cheap and can easily damaged your negatives if you aren’t careful. We ended up getting a different one and hoping this one works out better as we have a ton of negatives to process. My grandmother was the best at taking pictures and we don’t want to lose any memories. I definitely recommend to spend a little bit more to get better quality.
customer_reviews.author: Momma of 5

customer_reviews.title: continuation of my previous review -
customer_reviews.text: Sorry, my previous review must have gone... so I continue... The slide viewer is a good size and is very helpful. I did have trouble with the push-through slide feed getting stuck a few times, but fixing it only requires opening the tray, removing the previously viewed slide, positioning the current slide again, and restarting. This occurred infrequently because my slides are in pretty good shape despite being 50 years old. It probably helps to prevent this problem if you are slower and very deliberate in feeding. The problem occurs when the previous slide hangs up upon exiting. The slide tray has a small groove for slide alinement.
customer_reviews.author: Martha P. Bennett

customer_reviews.title: Efficient and Reliable
customer_reviews.text: I have used the scanner several times, converting 35mm slides to an SD memory card. The process is efficient and reliable. I now have several years of family photos stored on one SD memory card. Over 2000 slides fit on a 16GB memory card for easy retrieval and viewing. Almost all of the slides pushed through the scanning tray effortlessly. However, some were slightly too big and had to be manually scanned, which was not as convenient. Overall, this device is a lifesaver. No more getting out the slide projector, screen, and Kodak Carousel slide trays.
customer_reviews.author: DoublePlayBill

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use.
customer_reviews.text: I have hundreds of negatives going back to the 70's. This has helped me to quickly and easily go through them and scan the ones I want to digitize. You have to have an sd card but you can us the tv-out cord to easily uplead to your computer. The viewing creen is just big enough. I didn't use it for editing. I have yet to look at my 110 film but the 35MMS were very easy.
customer_reviews.author: Nancy

customer_reviews.title: Loved viewing old developed negatives with this
customer_reviews.text: Love this scanner. I bought it so I could view some old negatives that belonged to my late mother. I had to trim the edges off some of the larger negatives so they would fit but it was worth it. I got to see very old pictures of my mother’s family we had never seen. And it helped me realize how absolutely gorgeous my Mom was. Some of the photos were of Charleston, SC in the 1940’s. I loved the old pictures of Folly Beach and family enjoying the ocean. Well worth the money.
customer_reviews.author: Carole C

customer_reviews.title: LIFE SAVER!!!
customer_reviews.text: I had a fire many years ago and mostly was only able to save negatives after cleaning them from the water. They have been stored for 15+ years. THIS machine not only saved them to the SD card but allows me to adjust the color just as I remember the day the picture was taken. My parents are gone and the kids are grown. I was bawling as it pulled up one photo after another. My babies got new pics of their daddy who is gone now. It was so wonderful to be able to send the kids pictures of the daddy they didn't have. Photos of my parents when they were young. This is priceless!
customer_reviews.author: Kimmi

customer_reviews.title: My family has loved seeing these old photos again!
customer_reviews.text: As I've gone through old slides and negatives (some of which were 70 years old), I've been amazed at how crisp and clear the Kodak Scanza scans are. And the resolution is phenomenal! I'm coming away with 22MP scans of negatives that have been in a box for 70 years. When I zoom in on these photos, I get amazing detail. LOVE this product! Here's what I wish they could do next: have an automatic feeder for slide carousels. That would be AMAZING!
customer_reviews.author: Ben Clark

customer_reviews.title: Alignment of slide is off on the left side
customer_reviews.text: We had a large number of slides we needed to scan. This filled the bill. Once the learning curve was mastered we found this to be a quality, easy to use product. I did take a star off because no matter what I did the scanner would not include the far left of a slide. It was a very small amount, but if you want the far left of a slide you have to pull the slide over, scan it and then seam them together. It' a bit of a hassle and I don't know if it was only with our scanner, but it wasn't a "show stopper" and didn't prevent us from completing our slide scanning project.
customer_reviews.author: Nivek

customer_reviews.title: Good product for the price.
customer_reviews.text: So far we have tried it only on 35 mm slides and it is working. Our only complaint is that it is particular about getting the slide positioned just right or it jams a bit. It can be tedious doing one slide at a time and time consuming or slow. The pictures are good, slightly grainy but of decent quality overall. - At least we are getting them into digital.
customer_reviews.author: RunningBear

customer_reviews.title: Good but not great. Hard to load
customer_reviews.text: For 35mm slides and color negatives overall good. I have not tried it with any other format. The drawbacks: the image projected on the screen bears no resemblance to the final. Do not use the tools to make corrections they will be wrong. The way that slides feed is only one at a time, and don’t follow instructions. Feed slides through rack 1 or 3 don’t open the slide mount, for its very difficult. The images are fair as long as you do not want to go more than a 5x7. For the price,​ I was expecting more, but it does work.
customer_reviews.author: John Buono

customer_reviews.title: Does Not Convert 8mm/Super8mm Movies
customer_reviews.text: This devices is for converting still pictures only. It appears to work with negatives, slides and 8mm/Super 8mm film. BUT it does not convert moving video. I purchased it solely for the purpose of converting old home movies. It does not do that. I'll be returning it.
customer_reviews.author: LUCK

customer_reviews.title: Recovering some of my past
customer_reviews.text: I discovered a box of 60-year-old slides that my deceased father took when the kids in the family were young. I got the Scanza to recover the slides and digitize them in preparation for a Celebration of Life for my mother. Despite my nearly complete lack of technical skills, I quickly figured out the system and converted 235 slides in just a couple of hours. The digitized photos were faithful to the original shots and my siblings and I really valued resurrecting a five-year slice of our distant pasts. I was really pleased that I bought the Scanza.
customer_reviews.author: Satisfied customer

customer_reviews.title: A great low cost solution to digitize your slides
customer_reviews.text: Pushed 250 - 300 slides through this baby and it did a great job of converting them to digital files. Don't look for fancy software to change color cast or remove dust and take the photos and dump them in Lightroom or Photoshop for post processing. The basic/3mb file size selection is adequate for amateur slides taken over the years...if you are looking to convert important or professional slides, send them out to a repro shop.
customer_reviews.author: rbohl

product_meta.title: KODAK SCANZA Digital Film & Slide Scanner - Converts 35mm, 126, 110, Super 8 & 8mm Film Negatives & Slides to JPEG - Includes Large Tilt-Up 3.5" LCD, Easy-Load Film Inserts, Adapters & More
product_meta.description:
NOTE: Press The power Button for 3 seconds for the device to poer on 

NOTE: The Device will automaticly shut off after 10 minutes in not in use. 

NOTE: this is not a flatbed scanner, there is a 14mp camera built into the device that takes a snapshot of the film, if you are looking for HIGH quality scans please look for a flatbed scanner, this device is designed to quickly scan through old memories with good quality.

This Device only Scans Negative’s and film not Photos 

Please note the scanner can only scan film that has previously been developed, it CANNOT develop or scan raw film.

Also note super 8 converts to still images not video. 

also note that quality will be less than an image taken with a 22mp Digital Camera

Use the included brush to clean the light box of dust and speckles, to avoid marks on the scanned images. 

Features:
- Large 3.5” LCD Screen: helps you operate the scanner, view slideshows and edit images with handy tilt and adjustable brightness features.
- 14 Megapixel Sensor: captures images in stunning HD clarity.
- Integrated Interpolation: optional setting enhances images up to 22 megapixels.
- 3 Numbered Slide Inserts: easily adapt to your old films for safe, convenient loading.
- 3 Numbered Adapter Trays: hold the inserts and click into the unit for speedy scanning.
- Home Button: lets you navigate back to the interface’s main page.
- Capture Button: saves the current image or returns to the capture view screen.
- 3 Function Keys: correspond with various prompts on the screen for effortless interface navigation.
feature_bullets: FILM TO JPEG IN SECONDS – Powerful 14/22MP KODAK Film Scanner Converts Old 35mm, 126, 110, Super 8 & 8mm Negatives & Slides to JPEG Digital Files - NOTE; THE SCANZA WILL NOT CONVERT FILMS OTHER THEN 35mm, 126, 110, Super 8 & 8mm Negatives
LARGE, BRIGHT 3.5” TFT LCD – High Definition Built-In Color Display Features Adjustable Brightness & Convenient Tilt for Easy Operation & Image Viewing
AN ADAPTER FOR EVERYTHING – Unit Arrives w/Multiple Film Inserts & Adapters for Fast, Flexible Operation; Big One-Touch Buttons Allow for One-Step Scan & Save
INTUITIVE USER INTERFACE – Includes Helpful Tray & Insert Directory; Easily Edit Image RGB & Resolution, Browse Gallery [SD Card NOT Included, supports up to 128GB] & More

CABLES & EXTRAS INCLUDED – Mac & PC Compatible Converter Comes w/USB Power Cable, HDMI Cable, AC Adapter, Video Cable & FREE Film Cleaning Brush. Use the included brush to also clean the light box of dust and speckles, to avoid marks on the scanned images.

specifications.Customer Reviews: 4.2 out of 5 stars2,858 ratings4.2 out of 5 stars
